newsitem.title: USA: Lawyers spar in court over Orange County documents.
newsitem.headline: Lawyers spar in court over Orange County documents.

text.p: Orange County, Calif., attorneys and prosecutors clashed in court on Wednesday over grand jury transcripts that could shed light on Merrill Lynch & Co's role in the county bankruptcy crisis.
Superior Court Judge David Carter in Santa Ana heard nearly six hours of arguments from attorneys representing the county, local news organisations, the district attorney, Merrill Lynch and others.
At the end of the hearing, the judge said he needed time to review the testimony. He was expected to issue his ruling in the coming weeks.

Wall Street was rocked in December 1994 when Orange County filed for bankruptcy after losing more than $1.6 billion on risky investments. The southern California county emerged from bankruptcy one year ago.
In June, Merrill Lynch settled with Orange County's district attorney for $30 million, ensuring that the brokerage giant and its employees would not face criminal charges.

Lawyers for Orange County and local news organisations asked Carter to give them access to the grand jury transcripts, arguing that the public had a right to know what the panel learned about Merrill Lynch's part in the crisis.
County attorneys say the transcripts could also bolster their $2-billion-plus lawsuit against Merrill Lynch.
County prosecutors and Merrill Lynch contend the transcripts must remain sealed because no indictments were returned by the grand jury.
